Oliver Y. Chén

Painting

I paint Gōng-Bi (工筆) style watercolor (aquarelle); I also enjoy oil painting. Here are some of my paintings.

Tai Bai


Date painted: 2006
Ink on raw Xuan paper (宣紙), approx. 100 x 100 cm
Technique: Gong-bi (工筆)

Media Appearance

Pondering the Imponderables


Date painted: 2006
Ink on raw Xuan paper (宣紙), approx. 100 x 100 cm
Technique: Gong-bi (工筆)

L’horizon du port intérieur de Baltimore


Date painted: 2014
Watercolor and acrylic on canvas


On Exhibition: Baltimore, MD. (2015) Sponsored by the NAP (National Arts Program)

Ristorante Trattoria Sempione



Date painted: In progress
Oil on canvas, approx. 8 by 12 in.

Classical Music

I played trombone, trumpet, and Chinese Sornā; I love Chopin and Debussy; my favorite pianist is Horowitz. Below are a few pieces I find delightful (I put here for my personal convenient access, and would be pleased if you find some of them beautiful); I confess that they are rather subjective.

- Nr. 7, Träumerei in Kinderszenen, Op.15. Robert Schumann. The piece performed by Horowitz at the Moscow Conservatory in 1986 was a classic.
- Swan Lake Op. 20, Act I: No. 10. Scène: Moderato Pyotr Tchaikovsky.
- Swan Lake Op. 20, Act II: No. 10. Scène: Moderato Pyotr Tchaikovsky.
- Piano Concerto No. 1 in B-flat minor, Op. 23. Allegro non troppo e molto maestoso Pyotr Tchaikovsky.
- The Nutcracker Suite, Op. 71. Act II: Waltz of the Flowers (Valse des fleurs) Pyotr Tchaikovsky.
- Allegro maestoso of Concerto No. 1 in E Minor Op. 11. Frédéric Chopin.
- Nocturne in E-flat major, Op. 9, No. 2. Frédéric Chopin.
- Étude Op. 10, No. 3, in E major Frédéric Chopin.
- Suite No.1 in G Major (BWV 1007) Johann Sebastian Bach
- Libiamo ne’ lieti calici , from La traviata (based on La Dame aux Camélias (Alexandre Dumas, fils, 1852)) by Giuseppe Verdi
Historical note (from Wikipedia): The first act (of La traviata) was met with applause and cheering at the end; but in the second act, the audience began to turn against the performance, especially after the singing of the baritone Felice Varesi and the tenor Lodovico Graziani. The next day, Verdi wrote to his friend Emanuele Muzio in what has now become perhaps his most famous letter: “La traviata last night a failure. Was the fault mine or the singers’? Time will tell.”
- La donna è mobile , from Act 3 Rigoletto/i> by Giuseppe Verdi
- ’O sole mio (my sunshine), by Eduardo di Capua Lyricist: Giovanni Capurro
